The board storm doors have been taken off the front of the house and now lean on the porch... There's an old washtub in the back, full of dirt, where later flowers will grow. The Buick pulls into the yard. “Ethel jumps out, Norman follows slowly. Ethel dashes round the side of the * house down to the dock, making Loon calls. From the * distance the Loons answer. Ethel turns to Norman who * stands at the side of the house watching bemused. * wo, ETHEL ‘* Norman. The Loons: They heard me! * ‘Hello Golden Pond. We're here. * Norman fumbles with keys, and opens the door. Ethel * follows. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman and Ethel step into the living room. It is large; -high-ceilinged, comfortable-looking. There's a cheery glow from the lake, which can be SEEN THROUGH the large WINDOWS. The room is practically alive with character and history. Its furniture, eclectic and interesting, is mostly hidden now by dust covers, and the are porch chairs and tables piled up inside as well. On the walls we SEE an amazing chronicle of a family. Hundreds of photographs, diplomas and 4-H ribbons, and drawings, and yellowed newspaper clippings. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: The whole room, indsea, as we'll see, the whole house, is a huge album of memories. There are old fishing hats on-a rack, and old jackets, fishpoles, boat cushions, anchors, a water ski, knicknacks galore, pine cones, stuf fish, and the like, and hundreds of wonderful books, coll ections. of Dumas.and Twain and Dickens and Defoe and Stevenson and other masters of the ilk.

He wanders to the fish- poles. . “On the wall.is a ‘photo of Norman as a’ younger man hold ing two large fish. Norman stares at the picture. Beside it is a clipping whose headline reads, “Profes- sor Thayer Retires." It is dated 1966.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman opéns the wooden front door. He pushes the screen door, but instead of swinging open, it falls over onto the porch. Norman regards it for a moment, then steps back into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks~about? He lifts a dust cover and finds a fifties-style telephone on a small table. He lifts the receiver.and listens.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing; calling) The phone works! (to himsel£) At least I think it does. (he dials "0") Hello? Hello? Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He is distracted by a photo of himself and Ethel when they were both much younger.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who the hell is that? (he calls) Who the hell is in this picture here? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who the hell is that? Hello? Who is this?... The operator! What do you want?... You called, you must want something... Oh, wait a minute. I did call you, but you never answered... Well... How are you?... How nice. Listen. This is Norman Thayer, Jr. over on Golden Pond, and I have something I'd like you to do. Call me up. Can you do that?... I want to check my phone and make certain it still rings. It hasn't been rung all winter, and it may have lost its whatsis. Do you have ny mumber?... I have no idea, it has a nine in it, that's all I know... Well, it's in the book, you must have a book... Norman Thayer, Jr. Let's give it a try, shall we? Norman hangs up. He stares at the Phone expectantly. A moment passes. He squints at the photo.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who the hell is that? We HEAR a KNOCK at the DOOR. Norman is startled, He calls to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Someone's at the door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: ., (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: It's me, you old poop, She waits impatiently until at last Norman opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Well, look at you.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Yes, quite a sight, aren't 1?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethel marches in, Norman follows. He watches while she dumps her load of logs, and straightens up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Norman, it's so beautiful. Everything's just wating up. Little tiny birds, little tiny leaves. I saw a whole patch of little tiny flowers out by the old cellar hole. 1 forgot what they're called, little tiny yellow things.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What were you doing out there in the woods? °

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Getting firewood, what do you think I was doing? What happened to the screen door?

dialogues.speaker: . NORMAN
dialogues.text: It fell over.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I pushed it. -

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I Pushed the door and the door fell over. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What do you think of this one?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Quite a sight. Oh, no, poor Elmer has had a terrible fall.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Who's poor Elmer?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Elmer, my dolly. He fell into the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Well, he should be more careful.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Poor little Elmer. The life you've had. Did you know he turned sixty- five this spring?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No, I must say I wasn't aware of that. He tries on more hats, one of which he'll wear for the vest of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: My father got him for me on my fourth birthday. I wanted a red scooter, but my father said red scooters were excessive and contrary to the ways of the Lord. He told me I'd understand when I got older. Well, I'ma lot older now and I'm afraid I still don't understand. But he gave me Elmer. And Elmer and I, the times we've had. He was my first true love, you know.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I've known all along I wasn't the first in line.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: No, you were a rather cheap substitute for my darling Elmer. and now he's had a fall, poor ear. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee  23

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe he was trying to kill himself. Maybe he wants to be cremated. Probably got cancer or termites or something.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Are you hungry, darling?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No. It wouldn't be a bad way to go, huh? A quick front flip off the mantel, a bit of a kick at the last minute, and end up right in the fire. Nothing to it. ETHEL ° Shut up, Norman!

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: When my number's up, do that for me, would you? Prop me up on the mantel and point out which way is down, I may even try for a full gainer with a half twist.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Norman Thayer, will you shut up? Your fascination with dying is beginning to frazzle my good humor.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: It's not a fascination. It just crosses my mind now and then.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Every five minutes. Don't you have anything else to think about?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Nothing quite as interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Well, what's stopping you? Why don't you take your dive and get it over with? See what it's Like?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: And leave you alone with Elmer? You must be mad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee  23 24 25 ON GOLDEN POND ~ Rev. 6/28/80 10A.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, for pity’s sake. Come along with me and let's get the canoe off the porch. She opens the enclosed porch.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: All right. Grab an end. Norman takes one end, she lifts the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They plod slowly down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: This is not our canoe. It’s way too heavy. The PHONE RINGS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 26 27 ON GOLDEN POND ~- Rev. 6/28/80 11,

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Well, what do you know? The phone's ringing.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Who the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: I don't know, dear. She sets her end down. Norman sets down his. PHONE

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN -
dialogues.text: I'll get it. Maybe it's St. Peter. You take the canoe on down. He hurries back to the house. Ethel drags the canoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS. Norman enters. He Pauses @ moment to regain his breath. He lifts the receiver,

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Hello? Who is this?... The operator! What do you want?... Oh, to check the ring. Of course. Does it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman carries the phone onto the porch and watches as Ethel gathers up paddles and cushions, puts the binoc- ulars around her neck and carries them all down to the canoe.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I guess it did ring here. Thank you... I beg your pardon?,.. Oh. Thank you. He hangs up the phone and leaves it on the porch. He eutles down the bank shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) She said to have a nice day. What a strange thing to say. What did she think I was going to do? Well, the phone works. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on a rock and watches Ethel move sections of dock.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, guess whe else I ran into?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You ran into someone else? The woods are full of people. What's this place coming to?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: It was only Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: Who's Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Charlie, Norman. The mailman. He sai ‘d come round and put in our dock for us.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I'1L put in the dock.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: You won't put in the dock.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Because you're too old.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I'm not old at all. I'm middle- aged.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Charlie says our boat's all ready and he'll bring it on Saturday!

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: i remember Charlie when he was just a little fellow. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON GOLDEN POND ~ Rev. 6/28/80 13.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He used to laugh at anything. I thought then he was a bit deficient.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Chelsea had such a crush on him. Remember, Norman?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I could never understand that. He pulls himself up and studies the beached float,

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Remember Chelsea trying to be on the diving team at school? Ha, ha, ha, (he holds out his hands) She was about this wide. He climbs up on the diving board. He may take a jump or two while they talk.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Tsk. She wasn't any such thing. She had a few fat years, that's all. :

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I should say so. It's no wonder she could never do a back flip. No center of gravity.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Well,she tried... She only did it to please you, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, Norman. Wouldn't it be nice if I could persuade her to come and spend a few days this summer?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Mmm. Want to go up to the house and play a quick game of Parcheesi? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: POND ~ Rev. 6/28/80 13A,

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Not now, Norman. We've got the whole summer for you to try to win back the fortune you lost to me last year.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Heh heh.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: I hope you thought about your tactics over the winter.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Heh heh.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Pretty shoddy, some of those moves of yours.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Heh heh. The two of them stare out at the lake. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON GOLDEN POND - Rev. 6/10/80 14,

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Isn't it beautiful, Norman? He steps to her and puts his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Let's take a quick ride, shall we? First ride of the year.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: It's a little cold for that sort of thing, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Come on. She pushes the canoe into the water and holds the bow. He hesitates, but finally begins to climb in. The canoe rocks and Norman stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Good God.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Well, watch yourself.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I think you're trying to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: I've thought about it. At last he settles in. Ethel hands him a paddle, then climbs aboard, and they're off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman and Ethel in the canoe. She is paddling ener- getically in the bow. He igs faking it in the stern. The canoe, consequently, is veering crookedly.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Are you paddling, Norman?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Of course I'm paddling. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Then you're not steering. Do you want me to take the stern?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I most certainly do not. He tries a little harder. The canoe glides along by other cottages.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Charlie says he doesn't expect Miss Appley to make it up this summer.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Who's Miss Appley?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Miss Appley, Norman, who lives in there a Miss Tate. They're both in their nineties. They were up here together when I was a teenager. Wearing their neckties, and singing in the gazebo, Holding hands, What a marvelous love affair, if that's what it is.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Can you imagine being together so long?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot. Charlie says Miss Appley is just too frail and Miss Tate won't come without her. It's sad, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Norman and Ethel paddle up the shore. A fish breaks the water.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Norman! Look at the fish! My word, It's going to be a good summer. My father always said if the fish start jumping in May it's a good sign. We'll have to go to the village and get your license. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 ON GOLDEN POND - Rev. 6/28/80 16.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I don't think I'll be doing any fishing this time around.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: All right, Norman...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No point in wasting the money. You'd think they'd give the license free to an old case like me. It's not as though I'd come out here and deplete the entire bass population or anything. -

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: You always catch your share. You always have,

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Well, that's all behind me now.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: All right, Norman. They paddle without speaking for a moment. Suddenly Ethel's attention is caught by something. She shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Norman!

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Good God! What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: The loons! I've spotted the Loons! She scrambles back in the canoe to retrieve the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: (cont inuing) Oh, my goodness. They're so lovely. Here. Look. He takes the glasses and trains them on the water,

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do you see them? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No. Oh. Oh, my goodness. There they are.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Aren't they beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: They're huge! I've never seen such big loons in my life. ETHEL . Those are boats, you poop. Come in closer. He lowers the glasses. We SEE two loons, huge and black. They swim close to each other.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: (continuing) A husband and a wife. I think they're looking at us.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. They are. He waves.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: They're talking.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I can't make out what they're saying. Can you read beaks?

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Look! They're kissing. My word.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: How wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LOONS 30
dialogues.text: They do indeed seem to be kissing. But suddenly they lock around, wary. We HEAR the SOUND of a MOTORBOAT, loud and threatening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we SEE the boat, a runabout, sleek and fast, a young couple aboard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: MY God! What are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: 187A ON THE LAKE 218 7A
dialogues.text: The lake looks more golden than ever, with dabs of yellow and red reflecting in the water.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Norman. This is the first time I've really felt we're going to die.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I've known it all along.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: When I looked at you lying on the ground I could actually see + you dead. I could see you in your blue suit and a white starched shirt, lying in Thomas’ Funeral Parlor on Bradshaw Street.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: How did L look? ‘THEL Not good, Norman. You've been talking about dying ever since I met you. But today was the first time I've really felt it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: How does it feel? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: It feels... Odd. Cold, I guess. But-not that bad, really. Almost comforting, not so frightening, not such a bad place to go. don't know. : She looks at him, looks away. He reaches up and pulls her head to him.. She smiles at him, leans against him. After a moment he pulls himself up. ‘

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Well? Don't you want to say goodbye to the lake?

dialogues.speaker: . ETHEL

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LAKE 188
dialogues.text: The two loons light on the water for a moment, then rise again and soar away.

dialogues.speaker: ON NORMAN AND ETHEL 189
dialogues.text: They watch the loons.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Just the two of them now, Little baby's all grown up and moved to Los Angeles or somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ETHEL
dialogues.text: Hello, Golden Pond. We've come to say goodbye. They stare out at the lake. The CAMERA DRAWS BACK and we SEE Norman and Ethel, like the last summer flowers on the shore. Solitary figures. Not sad, but peace- ful and hopeful and proud. The CAMERA DRAWS BACK, AWAY, ABOVE them. They become smaller and smaller, but still visible and bright on the golden pond. FADE OUT.
